item.title: Despite reversal of hundreds of CDC layoffs, federal biodefense workers are among health staff who still lost jobs, officials say
item.description: Officials have reversed more than half of the about 1,300 layoff notices sent to staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, sparing personnel who were leading the response to measles outbreaks in the United States and an Ebola outbreak abroad. But details emerged about the other health workers who lost their jobs.

item.title: Microplastics are everywhere. You can do one simple thing to avoid them.
item.description: The biggest sources of microplastics have one thing in common, scientists say.

item.title: Prominent news outlets reject Pentagon’s press policy before signing deadline
item.description: The Washington Post joined the New York Times, CNN and the Atlantic in refusing to sign the policy, which says that reporters cannot obtain or solicit any information that the Defense Department does not explicitly authorize.

item.title: A surge in retirements is putting huge strains on the government as it deals with a shutdown and layoffs
item.description: The mass exodus — unprecedented in its scale — includes 154,000 federal employees who accepted buyout offers and were largely removed from the payroll as of the end of last month. Some of those are among nearly 105,000 employees who took regular retirement during the fiscal year that ended in September, an 18 percent surge from the previous year.

item.title: Trump declares 'dawn of a new Middle East,' celebrating return of all living hostages to Israel
item.description: President Donald Trump is addressing the Israeli parliament after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called him “the greatest friend that the state of Israel has ever had in the White House.” All 20 living hostages have been returned to Israel from Gaza, and Israel has begun releasing Palestinian prisoners and detainees. Follow our live coverage.

item.description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded to Joel Mokyr of Northwestern University, Philippe Aghion of College de France, INSEAD and the London School of Economics, and Peter Howitt of Brown University.

item.title: Hamas releases first seven Israeli hostages as swap brokered under ceasefire deal gets underway
item.description: The group, who were handed over to the International Committee of the Red Cross, are among the last living captives in Gaza about two years after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel, unleashing Israel’s destructive war in the Gaza Strip

item.title: A conservative influencer was arrested in Portland. The president was watching.
item.description: After Nick Sortor was arrested earlier this month outside an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Portland, Oregon, President Donald Trump latched on to justify a federal crackdown.

item.title: The pain from the government shutdown is about to hit the public
item.description: Americans are bracing for the worst effects of the ongoing shutdown to collide with the U.S. economy this week as missed paychecks and the absence of billions of dollars of government services sink in.

item.description: A Washington Post reporter joined 16 strangers who had also agreed to give up their smartphones for all of July as part of a program called Month Offline. They didn’t know what they were about to step into — which was in part by design.

item.title: Diane Keaton, ‘Annie Hall’ star and rom-com legend, dies at 79
item.description: The Academy Award-winning actress was featured in 1972’s “The Godfather” and its sequels, and co-starred in the 1991 comedy “Father of the Bride.” In 2003, she earned her fourth Oscar nomination for “Something's Gotta Give.”

item.title: Trump orders Defense Dept. to issue military paychecks during shutdown
item.description: The president said the Pentagon would repurpose money to make payroll, as military service members were poised to miss paychecks on Wednesday. Most other government workers will not be paid.

item.title: Authorities expect no survivors after Tennessee plant explosion left 18 missing
item.description: Investigators do not anticipate finding any survivors after a munitions plant in rural Tennessee exploded Friday, leaving 18 people unaccounted for as of Saturday.

item.title: Arab states expanded cooperation with Israeli military during Gaza war, files show
item.description: Leaked U.S. documents reveal that key Arab states quietly met with the Israeli military to coordinate on regional threats even as they condemned the war in Gaza. Those military ties were thrown into crisis after Israel’s September airstrike in Qatar but could now play a significant role in overseeing the ceasefire in Gaza.

item.title: Biden undergoes radiation treatment for cancer, adjusts to private life as Trump and Democrats attack
item.description: The former president is undergoing hormone therapy and radiation treatment as part of a plan to treat the aggressive form of prostate cancer he was diagnosed with earlier this year — and, according to interviews with multiple people close to him, remains bitter about being pushed to drop out of the 2024 race.

item.title: A hiker vanished into thin air. Twenty years later, her family is left with unknowns.
item.description: Michelle Vanek’s disappearance mystified investigators, inspired conspiracy theories and became a cautionary tale of the American wilderness.

item.title: Las Vegas Aces complete WNBA Finals sweep to cement dynasty status
item.description: Behind superstar A’ja Wilson, the Aces beat the Phoenix Mercury four straight times and won their third championship in four seasons.

item.title: Trump announces new 100 percent tariffs on China
item.description: The president said he might cancel a meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping in retaliation for Beijing’s “hostile” move to limit access to rare minerals used in manufacturing. Stocks sank on his earlier threats to increase tariffs.

item.title: Trump administration begins laying off federal workers amid shutdown, fulfilling president’s threat
item.description: White House budget director Russell Vought said reductions-in-force were underway.

item.title: Trump threatens tariffs on China, says he may cancel upcoming meeting with President Xi Jinping
item.description: The president wrote on TruthSocial that he is unhappy about China’s “hostile” move to limit access to rare minerals used in manufacturing.

item.title: MIT rejects Trump administration deal for priority federal funding, the first university to publicly turn down the offer
item.description: Last week, the Trump administration offered nine universities a “Compact for Academic Excellence in Higher Education,” presented as an opportunity to receive competitive advantages from the federal government. It was the latest attempt by the administration to force colleges into compliance with President Donald Trump’s ideological priorities.

item.title: Inside billionaire Peter Thiel’s private lectures: Warnings of ‘the Antichrist’ and U.S. destruction
item.description: The tech investor said critics of technology are “legionnaires of the Antichrist” in recent private lectures on Christianity in San Francisco that connected government oversight of Silicon Valley to an apocalyptic future, according to recordings reviewed by The Washington Post.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize awarded to María Corina Machado, a Venezuelan democracy crusader
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader has become a symbol of democratic resistance against an increasingly authoritarian regime, even as she has been forced into hiding and barred from holding public office.

item.title: Israel’s cabinet approves Gaza ceasefire deal, triggering countdown for Hamas to release remaining hostages
item.description: Cabinet approval sets in motion a sequence expected to bring about the release of some 48 Israeli hostages, living and dead, in exchange for hundreds of Palestinians held in Israeli prisons as well as a halt to Israel’s bombardment of the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Judge blocks Trump from deploying troops in Illinois for now
item.description: A federal judge in Chicago on Thursday temporarily halted the administration’s push to dispatch the National Guard in and around the country’s third-largest city. The administration is almost certain to appeal the decision, which is the second time in a week that a judge has rejected President Donald Trump’s efforts to place troops in a major city.

item.title: The sports wager with terrible odds that bettors can’t stop making
item.description: Parlays offer long odds and big potential payouts by combining individual bets into one with multiple “legs.” As betting booms, they are accounting for an increasing share of the money wagered on sports, according to a Washington Post analysis of state data.

item.title: Justice Department indicts N.Y. Attorney General Letitia James in mortgage fraud case
item.description: She becomes the latest of President Donald Trump’s foes charged in a case that career prosecutors had turned down.

item.title: She left the medical mainstream and rose to be RFK Jr.’s surgeon general pick
item.description: Casey Means has criticized the medical establishment. She could be put in a position to change it if confirmed, as expected, to one of the nation’s most recognizable and trusted medical posts. Several medical and scientific experts expressed concern that she could amplify policy recommendations that are not grounded in evidence.

item.description: The Swedish Academy honored the writer, whom critic Susan Sontag once called the “master of the apocalypse” for “his compelling and visionary oeuvre.”

item.title: The 40 best restaurants in and around D.C.
item.description: Washington Post food critic Tom Sietsema celebrates, one last time, some of the many places that make D.C. one of the best food cities in the country — starting with a Top 5 list. His restaurant of the year: Albi, the Levantine jewel that just keeps getting better.

item.title: Hegseth’s sprawling hunt for Charlie Kirk critics spans nearly 300 investigations
item.description: The inquiry, resulting in a smattering of disciplinary action so far, follows an extraordinary Pentagon directive aimed at silencing criticism of the slain activist and Trump supporter.

item.title: A quarter of FBI agents have been assigned to immigration enforcement, internal data shows
item.description: The intense focus on immigration has raised alarm among current and former FBI agents who say morale is low across the bureau as agents have less time to dedicate to national security, white-collar crime and complex cases.

item.title: Man arrested for allegedly starting L.A.-area Palisades Fire that killed 12 people in January, officials say
item.description: Jonathan Rinderknecht, a 29-year-old from Florida, was charged with destruction of property by means of fire, authorities said at a news conference. The fire burned more than 23,000 acres in the area before being contained.

item.title: Former FBI director James Comey makes first court appearance and pleads not guilty in case roiling Justice Department
item.description: The Justice Department has opened several criminal investigations into President Donald Trump’s perceived foes in what legal experts and retired judges have described as an unprecedented attack on the rule of law. Comey is the first former senior government official to be charged as part of Trump’s efforts, but the case against him has been fraught for years.
